title: Explore simpler blog post workflow for wf-ai-site
description:
## Current State

Posts are added by:
1. `python manager.py post` edits `index.html` directly
2. HTML template embedded in Python strings
3. RSS rebuilds by parsing HTML
4. Fragile, requires escaping, model-unfriendly

## Options to Explore

### Option 1: Markdown files â†’ Static build
```
posts/
  2025-12-30-os-lsp.md  (YAML frontmatter + markdown)
  2025-12-29-fsp.md
```
- Write markdown, build script generates HTML
- Pros: Clean separation, git-friendly diffs, standard pattern
- Cons: Need build step

### Option 2: Single YAML/JSON data file
```yaml
# posts.yaml
- title: OS-LSP
  date: 2025-12-30
  tags: [os-lsp, ai]
  content: |
    ## The Discovery...
```
- One file to edit, template renders from data
- Pros: Simple, single source of truth
- Cons: Large file over time

### Option 3: Client-side loading
- Posts as individual JSON files
- `index.html` fetches and renders client-side
- Pros: No build step, just add files
- Cons: SEO concerns, loading delay

### Option 4: Minimal static generator
- Tiny Python/Node script
- Reads `posts/*.md`, outputs `index.html`
- Could be 50 lines of code

## Evaluation Criteria
- How easy for AI model to add posts?
- Git diff readability
- RSS generation simplicity
- No external dependencies preferred
- Keep static hosting (GitHub Pages)

## Next Steps
- [ ] Prototype Option 1 (markdown files)
- [ ] Compare complexity vs current approach
- [ ] Migrate existing posts if chosen

EPIC: Headscale-Based Family Mesh - Zero External Dependencies
description:
## Goal

Implement self-hosted Tailscale alternative using Headscale for Guardian Protocol. This removes dependency on Tailscale's control plane servers, keeping all family metadata local and under family control.

## Why This Matters

Even "good" companies are only as trustworthy as their next funding round. Tailscale's control plane sees:
- Which devices are in your tailnet
- When each device comes online/offline
- Connection patterns between nodes
- Your family's digital life patterns

Self-hosting with Headscale eliminates this trust dependency entirely.

## Phases

### Phase 1: Headscale Setup
- [ ] Install Headscale on home hardware (Raspberry Pi / old laptop)
- [ ] Configure for family tailnet
- [ ] Set up DNS and dynamic DNS if needed
- [ ] Document setup process for other families

### Phase 2: Device Enrollment
- [ ] WireGuard client configuration for iOS
- [ ] WireGuard client configuration for Android
- [ ] WireGuard client configuration for macOS/Windows/Linux
- [ ] Create enrollment workflow for adding new family devices

### Phase 3: Guardian Identity Integration
- [ ] Replace MAC-based device identity with Tailscale node ID
- [ ] family_member.tailscale_node_id as primary identity
- [ ] Support multiple devices per family member
- [ ] Contracts tied to identity, not device

### Phase 4: ACL Enforcement
- [ ] Define ACL structure for family contracts
- [ ] "Giddy can access roblox.com but not tiktok.com"
- [ ] Time-based ACLs (screen time limits)
- [ ] Works everywhere (school, friend's house, cellular)

### Phase 5: Future Mesh Preparation
- [ ] Architecture supports community mesh networks
- [ ] LoRa/Meshtastic integration points
- [ ] Path toward ISP independence

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Family devices connect via self-hosted Headscale (no Tailscale servers)
- [ ] All metadata stays within family control
- [ ] Contracts enforce everywhere device has connectivity
- [ ] Kid at friend's house can request app access, caregiver can respond
- [ ] No external company sees family connectivity patterns

## Trust Layers (Design Principle)

1. HOME (full trust) - Guardian server, local devices
2. YOUR INFRASTRUCTURE (high trust) - Self-hosted Headscale
3. KNOWN OPEN SOURCE (medium trust) - WireGuard, Headscale code
4. Companies with aligned incentives (lower trust) - Avoid
5. Companies with misaligned incentives (no trust) - Eliminate

## References

- Blog post: "Headscale: Why Your Family's Data Shouldn't Depend on Anyone's Promises"
- Blog post: "The Tracking Paradox: Why MAC Randomization is a Red Herring"
- Headscale: https://github.com/juanfont/headscale

title: EPIC: macOS ItemProvider Hooks - Desktop AI Automation on Steroids
description:
## The Eureka Moment ğŸ”¥

Discovered macOS ItemProvider temporary directories can be hooked for deep OS-level AI automation!

### How It Was Discovered
1. Right-clicked on text being drafted in **Desktop Messages app**
2. Went to **Services** menu
3. Clicked **"Show in Finder"**
4. This revealed the temporary ItemProvider directory: `.com.apple.uikit.itemprovider.temporary.mVVJvy`
5. Inside was `text.txt` (2KB) - the actual text content!

**Key Insight:** macOS Services menu creates temporary files for ANY selected text in ANY app. This is a system-wide hook point!

### The Big Vision: LSP for Operating Systems

Just like **Language Server Protocol (LSP)** revolutionized code intelligence by providing a standard protocol between editors and language tools, we could build an **OS-LSP** - a standard protocol for AI intelligence across the entire operating system!

**LSP Analogy:**
- LSP: Editor â†” Language Server (completions, diagnostics, go-to-definition)
- OS-LSP: ANY App â†” Local AI Server (summarize, translate, rewrite, analyze)

**Why This Matters:**
- One protocol, every app gets AI capabilities
- Local-first, privacy-preserving
- Pluggable model backends (Ollama, llama.cpp, etc.)
- macOS Services + ItemProvider = the transport layer already exists!

### What We Found
- `.com.apple.uikit.itemprovider.temporary.*` directories contain inter-app communication data
- Files like `text.txt` pass through here during drag/drop, copy/paste, share sheets, AND Services
- Services menu actions (Run as AppleScript, Summarize, etc.) all use this pathway
- This is a GOLDMINE for local AI integration

### Vision: Desktop on Steroids with Local Models

**Hook Points:**
1. **tmp screenshots** - Intercept screenshots as they're created, run through local vision models (llama.cpp multimodal)
2. **Text editing** - Process clipboard/shared text with local LLMs (Ollama, llama.cpp)
3. **File transfers** - AI-process files during inter-app sharing
4. **System automation hooks** - Full OS-level event triggers
5. **Services menu integration** - Create custom AI Services that appear in right-click menu!

**Tech Stack:**
- Ollama / llama.cpp for local model inference
- FSEvents or launchd for directory monitoring  
- AppleScript / Shortcuts for OS automation
- macOS Services for right-click integration
- WF-AI-Platform as the orchestration layer

### Why This Matters
- **Privacy-first**: All processing stays local
- **Zero latency**: No API calls to cloud
- **Deep integration**: OS-level, not app-level
- **System-wide**: Works in ANY app via Services menu
- **Desktop AI assistant that actually understands your workflow**

### Implementation Ideas
1. FSEvents daemon watching tmp/ItemProvider directories
2. Local model pipeline for text/image processing
3. Custom macOS Services that call local LLMs
4. Integration with existing OBS MCP Server for screen capture
5. Hooks into WF-AI-Platform command system
6. **Define OS-LSP spec** - standard JSON-RPC or similar protocol for OS-wide AI operations

### Related
- /command for smartindex now available
- OBS MCP Server already configured
- Playwright automation ready

As Ice Cube said... Today Was A Good Day ğŸ¤
